content: The "Child Care Infrastructure Act of 1996" allows for a credit for employer expenses for child care assistance under the new section 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Child Care Infrastructure Act of 1996" introduces a credit for employer-provided child care expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit is 50% of qualified child care expenditures, not exceeding $150,000 per year. Qualified expenditures include costs for property used as a child care facility. The "Child Care Infrastructure Act of 1996" introduces a credit for employer-provided child care expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. Special rules apply for aggregation, pass-thru in estates and trusts, and allocation in partnerships. No double benefit is allowed, with a reduction in basis for tax purposes. The rules of subsection (d) of section 52 apply to the allocation of the credit among partners in partnerships. No double benefit is allowed, with a reduction in basis for tax purposes. The basis of property is reduced by the determined credit amount. If there is a recapture amount in a taxable year, the basis of the property is increased by that amount. No other deductions or credits are allowed under this chapter. The term 'recapture amount' refers to any increase in tax determined under subsection (d). No other deductions or credits are allowed with respect to the credit amount. This section does not apply to taxable years after December 31, 1999. Amendments are made to Section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new paragraph for the employer-provided child care credit under section 45D. Additionally, a new item is added to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1996.
